> How can I avoid this type of error? This one wasn't so critical as it can be in large crawl because I intend to end this crawl soon.

This looks like the same issue as discussed in this previous message:

http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/archive-crawler/message/5859

Increasing the 'ulimit -n' open-file limit *may* help, but also getting 
to the JVM versioned 1.6.0_14 should address the underlying Java bug.

> Second thing I have on my mind. Can I just rename arc.gz.open files to arc.gz and use it for indexing?

For the most part, yes. However, because the crash may have occurred 
midway through writing a record, the last record may be incomplete 
(either as a record or a gzip compression envelope). Usually later 
indexing steps are robust against such corruption, but the best practice 
is probably to validate the ARC and truncate-away any incomplete final 
record before 'sealing'/ingesting the ARC.

We have a legacy tool (not part of the open-source packages) that does 
this for ARCs but not WARCs, but it should be easy to make a tool, 
either from the ARCReading functionality (such as by using a CDX 
index-of-records to identify the last good record, and discarding areas 
afterward) or even from gzip tools (to find and discard the 
last/incomplete gzip envelope).

I've made an issue to track the idea such a tool should be part of the 
crawler, HER-1647. We'd welcome a contribution, if anyone has working 
shell/Java code for doing this.

- Gordon @ IA
